scenes.audio: Totally. scenes.audio: And it makes me think about us as readers. We're drawn into this confession, we're listening to Clemence's story, but are we part of the problem? That's the question Camus wants us to ask ourselves: are we complicit in this cycle of judgment and confession?

scenes.audio: It's like we're all in that bar together, trying to make sense of our own guilt and our own need for redemption. And Camus doesn't give us any easy answers. He leaves us to wrestle with these questions on our own.

scenes.audio: So this Clemence guy, he calls himself a judge-penitent, right? Right. But is he really looking for redemption? That's the question, isn't it? It's like he's saying, "Look at how terrible I am, but at least I'm honest about it unlike all of you." Exactly. Like he's found a loophole where self-condemnation equals absolution.
scenes.visuals: Image of a man in a suit on a cracked pedestal facing a crowd. Text overlay revisits the judge-penitent, questioning redemption vs. superiority, and discusses self-condemnation as absolution, defining terms.

scenes.audio: Totally. By preemptively judging himself, he's trying to shut down any judgment that might come from others. And it's working, isn't it? But that's the thing about Clemence. scenes.visuals: Image of a large spiderweb transitions to a shattered mirror image reflecting a woman's eye. Text overlay discusses preemptive judgment and drawing the reader in, defining terms.

scenes.audio: Trapped with him listening to his confession. But also kind of judging him at the same time. And that's what Camus is so brilliant at. scenes.audio: So where does that leave us? Are we all doomed to this cycle of judgment and self-deception? I don't think Camus is trying to give us a definitive answer.
